awd_titl_txt: Mesoscale Vortex Dynamics in Tropical Weather Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Tropical cyclone development remains a difficult forecast problem.  The objective of this research project is to study the complex motions that occur in a tropical weather system and how they interact to either assist or hinder tropical cyclone development.  The impact of the project will be to help improve tropical cyclone forecast models that are relied upon for public safety.  The project also includes an internship opportunity to enhance workforce development. 

This project is focused on the nature and consequences of complex mesoscale vortex interactions that occur in tropical weather systems.  The research activities will advance knowledge of the mechanisms that control mesoscale vortex merger and alignment under various scenarios, when oceanic surface fluxes, cloud processes and radiation have the potential to strongly affect the dynamics.  Idealized numerical modeling using the Cloud Model 1 model will comprise the bulk of the study and is intended to help answer the main two research questions:  1) How do mesoscale vortex interactions influence tropical cyclone development? 2) How do diabatic mesoscale vortices interact, and what controls the nature of their interaction?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In general terms, the main objective of this research project was to improve our understanding of how weak and asymmetric tropical cyclones intensify into potentially devastating hurricanes.  This objective was achieved primarily through computational studies using a cloud resolving weather research model.  The computational studies focused on investigating how a misalignment of the low-level and midlevel circulations of a tropical cyclone (a "tilt") affects the pathway and time scale of intensification. One notable finding was that even if environmental wind shear becomes minimal, a sufficiently large lingering tilt can increase the time scale of hurricane formation over a moderately warm ocean by an order of magnitude.  The pathway of intensification was often seen to involve an extended period of slow spinup during which the tilt tends to decay, followed by a sharp transition to a period of fast spinup involving appreciable contraction of the vortex core.  The decay of tilt generally coincided with the enhancement of thermodynamic conditions favorable to deep cumulus convection inward of the maximum surface winds.  The mean transitional values of the tilt magnitude and of certain thermodynamic parameters measuring the conduciveness of inner conditions to deep convection (with one reported exception) were found to change significantly with variation of the sea surface temperature from 26 to 30 degrees Celsius.  Furthermore, the decay of tilt that controls the timing of the transition to fast spinup was often seen to occur in several mechanically distinct stages, including a partially regressive intermediate stage of transient growth.  The roles of diabatic forcing (cumulus convection) and adiabatic vortex dynamics during each stage of the tilt evolution were assessed.  

One essential feature of a misaligned tropical cyclone is a concentration of relatively strong cumulus convection--- which drives intensification ---into a region downtilt of the surface vortex center.  The thermo-fluid dynamics responsible for maintaining this asymmetric distribution of convection in our cloud resolving simulations was thoroughly analyzed.  Moreover, theoretical and reduced modeling studies were conducted to gain novel insights into how the concentration of convection downtilt affects the nature of intensification within and beyond the parameter regime explored by our cloud resolving simulations.  The intensification mechanism was found to depend on whether the strength of the low-level convergence associated with downtilt convection exceeds a critical magnitude dependent on various factors such as the vector difference between the drift velocity of the convergence zone and the component of the local fluid velocity attributable to the broader cyclonic circulation.  Supercritical convergence was found to induce an abrupt "core replacement" event followed by rapid spinup.  Subcritical convergence was found to induce a slower mode of intensification that varies with additional system parameters.  One particular slow mode of intensification involved a gradual approach of the vortex center toward the convergence zone, coinciding with a reduction of the radius of maximum wind speed.  Another slow mode of intensification involved no such approach, nor any appreciable contraction of the inner core.

A secondary objective of this research project was to improve our understanding of internal processes that are linked to substantial intensity fluctuations of mature hurricanes.  Conventional wisdom suggests that gradual changes of subtle details of the basic hurricane structure may at some point cause an inner core instability that results in transient weakening of the vortex.  A new theoretical framework was developed for studying such instabilities.  Specifically, existing theory was generalized to account for how the cyclone-scale overturning secondary circulation, perturbations to the diabatic forcing, and spatial variation of turbulent transport parameters affect the mechanics of an instability and the conditions for its occurrence.  The new theory has suggested that older theories neglecting the aforementioned factors are sometimes quite deficient in their predictions of the most relevant instabilities.  

All major findings of this research project have been disseminated to the pertinent scientific communities and to the general public through conference presentations and a number of peer reviewed journal articles.  The broader impacts of this project should be far reaching.  Knowledge gained from our basic research is now available to assist efforts to improve operational forecasts of intensity change, which determine the preparations needed to adequately mitigate damage to coastal or island communities that lie in the predicted path of a tropical cyclone.  Furthermore, the participation of an undergraduate student and a postdoctoral researcher in various activities associated with this project has contributed to the development of the next generation of engineers and scientists.
